ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Before We Eat. We learned about what farmers do. We learned about all of the different things they do to get food to our tables.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of people doing different activities and say if they are farmers.

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: group is for people who are doing things that a farmer would do on a farm.
The other group is for people who are not farmers.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Hand Signals Ask children to give a thumbs-up if the picture shows something a farmer does or a thumbs-down if it does not. Model using the first picture card.
Ask Show one picture card to the group and ask the question on the back of the card. Offer extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Sort Make a sign for each group—“farmer” and “not a farmer.” Give the picture card to a child to line up under the correct column.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: We’ve learned a lot about what farmers do to get us the food we eat every day. Let’s talk about what happens when the food leaves the farm. Ask children questions about what they saw in the book. For example, show pages 20 to 26 and invite children to talk about what is happening in each image.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Use the Before We Eat to remind children of the different things farmers do. For example, for the first picture card, show the pages in the book (pages 4 and 5) where farmers plow and plant seeds. Review this with children before continuing the on to the next picture card.

Encourage children to participate in peer-to-peer conversations about each picture card, with each child taking two turns in the conversation. Remind children that while one person is talking, the other is listening. The talker should hold the card as a reminder of this.

Model and encourage children to use a physical response, in addition to speaking, to talk about what the farmers are doing in the pictures. For example, they use their hands to do a digging motion, or pretending to gather eggs one at a time to put them in a basket.

Encourage a conversation about the different foods and how they are made. One conversation strategy is to restate what a child has said and then immediately ask: Is that what you meant? By restating what a child has said, you validate their contributions, make sure that you understood the child correctly, and model correct language. Eventually, you can have children restate what their classmates have said using the same method of asking directly: Is that what you meant? Children will listen more closely to their classmates if they know that you may ask for volunteers to restate what the classmate just said.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Before We Eat. We talked about rules and routines in our classroom. Farmers have routines. We all have routines, too!
Following rules and routines keeps us safe and healthy.
Let’s talk about the word routine since it has something to do with the game we will play today.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Use the routine Vocabulary Card to revisit the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: I will show a picture of one of the routines you have to follow in our classroom. Then you will guess what the routine is.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and use the text on the back of the card to support and challenge as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the game using the next picture card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Why are routines in the classroom important? How do they help us? What other routines can you think of in class? Can you think of any routines that you follow at home?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Assist children by reminding them of the classroom routines they followed the day before. Asking children to describe what is happening in the pictures will help them identify the routine.

Encourage children to play charades by randomly choosing a card without letting their partner see it, and then acting out the routine they see on the front of the card. Their partner will guess which routine they are acting out.

Charades is a wonderful activity for multilingual learners, who can show what they know even if they are hesitant to use words. Encourage these learners’ creativity by asking them to show specific parts of the rule or routine. For example: “Show me what you do with your apple core” or “How do you rinse the soap off your hands?”
Give students plenty of room to act out the rule or routines of the classroom. Invite students to act out routines they follow at home.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Before We Eat. We read about people sharing a meal and working together. Sharing food is great, but sometimes problems come up and we have to find a way to solve them.
In this activity we’ll look at pictures that show problems. We will find out what the problem is and see if we can find a solution.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card, and then ask the question on the back of the card. Offer extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: The first thing we did was identify, or name, the problems we saw. How does naming the problem help? What do you do when you need to figure out how to solve a problem?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Invite children to describe what they see in the picture. Describing what they see might help children identify what the problem might be.

Encourage children who need a greater challenge to suggest additional solutions. Remind them that many problems have more than one solution. Ask questions to help children elaborate on their solutions, such as, How would doing that help solve the problem?

Model and encourage children to use both verbal and nonverbal language, such as gestures, to talk about the problems in the pictures or their solutions. For example, a child could mime breaking a cookie in half and offering half to a partner as a solution to the picture of children struggling over a cookie.

Offer children the option to draw their solutions using the picture on the card as a jumping off point. Using pencils, crayons, or markers, let children show what the picture would look like after applying the solution they propose. Encourage children to talk as they draw, using as many describing words as possible.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Let’s Make Fruit Salad! It included a food that almost everyone loves to eat—fruit!
When you make an inference, you use clues and your background knowledge to make a smart guess. A fruit is a food that:
In this activity, we will talk about different foods. Since we know the features of fruits, we can make smart guesses, or inferences, about whether the food we see in the picture is a fruit.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card. Offer extra support or challenge as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Show the next card and repeat steps above.
Talk about Fruit Ask children if it was hard to think of any of the pictures they saw as fruit, even if they had all the features of a fruit. Encourage conversation.
Talk about Foods Encourage children to talk about other fruits they like. Find a picture of a tomato. Discuss how a tomato has the features of a fruit but is often considered a vegetable.

If children cannot identify every food, assure them that they can ask whether the food pictured has the first two features of a fruit. Model: I see the food has seeds, and it is from a plant. I know fruits have seeds and come from a plant. This food is a fruit.
Encourage children to describe similar features of the other foods they have seen. Challenge them to sort the rest of the cards into two groups.

Encourage multilingual learners to share the names of all the foods in their home languages. If children are shy about speaking their home language, learn the names yourself, and ask students to point to that food. Children whose first language is Spanish may recognize the Spanish cognates fruta, planta, papaya, and brócoli. Help children make these connections, freeing their minds for the important executive function skill of classifying and organizing.

Encourage a conversation about the features of different foods. One conversation strategy is to restate what a child says and then immediately ask: Is that what you meant? By restating what a child has said, you validate their contributions. Eventually, you can have children restate what their classmates have said using the same method.
